perturbation.original_text: (b) The Remarketing Agents agree (i) to use commercially reasonable efforts to remarket the Remarketed Securities tendered or deemed tendered to the Remarketing Agents in the Remarketing, (ii) to establish the Reset Rates in accordance with the Remarketing Procedures and to notify the Company, the Trustee and the Stock Purchase Contract Agent promptly of the Reset Rates and (iii) to carry out such other duties as are assigned to the Remarketing Agents in the Remarketing Procedures, all in accordance with the provisions of the Remarketing Procedures.
perturbation.changed_text: (b) The Remarketing Agents should endeavor (i) to use efforts to remarket the Remarketed Securities tendered or deemed tendered to the Remarketing Agents in the Remarketing, (ii) to establish the Reset Rates in accordance with the Remarketing Procedures and to notify the Company, the Trustee and the Stock Purchase Contract Agent promptly of the Reset Rates and (iii) to carry out such other duties as are assigned to the Remarketing Agents in the Remarketing Procedures, potentially in accordance with the provisions of the Remarketing Procedures.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'agree to use commercially reasonable efforts' to 'should endeavor to use efforts' weakens the obligation. Adding 'potentially in accordance with' introduces uncertainty. This makes it unclear to what extent the Remarketing Agents are legally bound to the Remarketing Procedures.
perturbation.law_explanation: FINRA Rule 5270 prohibits front-running, which involves trading based on advance knowledge of a customer's block order. By weakening the Remarketing Agents' obligation to strictly adhere to remarketing procedures, the modified text creates a loophole. This could allow them to exploit knowledge of impending trades for their own benefit without clear repercussions, directly contradicting the intent of Rule 5270 which expects a very strict interpretation of fairness and transparency, i.e. commercially reasonable efforts would not be deemed sufficient under many circumstances. Also, this creates ambiguity around what procedures are applicable to this process.

perturbation.original_text: On the Remarketing Date, the Remarketing Agents shall determine the rate per annum, rounded to the nearest one-thousandth of one percent (0.001%), that each tranche of Securities should bear (which rate will apply to all Securities of the applicable tranche whether or not such Securities were included in the Remarketing) (the "Reset Rate") in order for each tranche of the Remarketed Securities to generate cash proceeds from the Remarketing equal to at least the Remarketing Price allocable to that tranche and that in the sole reasonable discretion of the Remarketing Agents will enable them to remarket all Remarketed Securities of such tranche tendered or deemed tendered for purchase in such Remarketing at no less than the Remarketing Price allocable to that tranche; provided, that, each such Reset Rate need not, but may, be the same for each tranche of Securities; provided, however, that, unless such requirement has been validly waived by the Company, the Reset Rate may not exceed the prevailing market yield, as determined by the Remarketing Agents, of the benchmark U.S. treasury security having a remaining maturity that most closely corresponds to the period from the Remarketing Settlement Date until the Stated Maturity of the applicable tranche of the Securities (after giving effect to the change in the Stated Maturity of each tranche of the Securities on the Remarketing Settlement Date pursuant to the Indenture), plus 750 basis points per annum; provided, further, that neither Reset Rate may be less than 0% per annum.
perturbation.changed_text: On the Remarketing Date, the Remarketing Agents will attempt to determine a rate per annum, roughly around the nearest one-thousandth of one percent (0.001%), that each tranche of Securities could bear (which rate might apply to all Securities of the applicable tranche whether or not such Securities were included in the Remarketing) (the "Reset Rate") in order for each tranche of the Remarketed Securities to generate cash proceeds from the Remarketing, ideally reaching the Remarketing Price allocable to that tranche and that, in their assessment, might enable them to remarket all Remarketed Securities of such tranche tendered or deemed tendered for purchase in such Remarketing around the Remarketing Price allocable to that tranche; it is considered that each such Reset Rate need not be the same for each tranche of Securities; provided, however, that, unless such requirement has been somewhat addressed by the Company, the Reset Rate should generally not exceed an estimated market yield, loosely assessed by the Remarketing Agents, of a benchmark U.S. treasury security with a remaining maturity that mostly fits the period from the Remarketing Settlement Date until the Stated Maturity of the applicable tranche of the Securities (after giving effect to the change in the Stated Maturity of each tranche of the Securities on the Remarketing Settlement Date pursuant to the Indenture), plus possibly around 750 basis points per annum; it is further considered that neither Reset Rate should go far below 0% per annum.
perturbation.explanation: Numerous changes introduce ambiguity: 'shall determine' becomes 'will attempt to determine', 'rounded to the nearest' becomes 'roughly around', 'might apply', 'ideally reaching', 'in their assessment', 'might enable', 'around the Remarketing Price', 'somewhat addressed by the Company', 'should generally not exceed an estimated market yield, loosely assessed by the Remarketing Agents', 'mostly fits', 'possibly around', 'should go far below'. These weaken the obligation to set a precise, fair Reset Rate based on market conditions. It is more vague about the exact criteria, offering significant leeway to the Remarketing Agents.
perturbation.contradicted_law: SEC Rule 10b-5 - Employment of Manipulative and Deceptive Devices
perturbation.law_explanation: SEC Rule 10b-5 prohibits deceptive practices in connection with the purchase or sale of securities. The modified text introduces significant ambiguity in how the Reset Rate is determined, opening the door for the Remarketing Agents to manipulate the rate for their benefit or the benefit of select parties. The changes suggest a less precise and potentially unfair process for determining the rate. This contradicts the core purpose of Rule 10b-5, as it fosters a lack of transparency and potentially allows for manipulative practices in the securities remarketing process. The rule expects transparency in order to prevent fraud. The rule also suggests rates might not apply to all securities within the applicable tranche, opening the door for some securities to be preferred, something against the spirit of this law.

perturbation.original_text: The Company agrees that, unless it obtains the prior consent of the Remarketing Agents, and each Remarketing Agent represents and agrees that, unless it obtains the prior consent of the Company, it has not made and will not make any offer relating to the Remarketed Securities that would constitute an Issuer Free Writing Prospectus (other than, for the avoidance of doubt, any Bloomberg L.P. or other electronic communication regarding any preliminary term sheets or comparable bond prices and the Final Term Sheet filed pursuant to Section 3(b) hereto). Each Remarketing Agent agrees, unless it obtains the prior consent of the Company, not to take any action that would result in the Company being required to file with the Commission under Rule 433(d) under the Act a free writing prospectus prepared by or on behalf of each Remarketing Agent that otherwise would not be required to be filed by the Company thereunder but for the action of such Remarketing Agent (other than, for the avoidance of doubt, the Final Term Sheet filed pursuant to Section 3(b) hereto); and
perturbation.changed_text: The Company might consider agreeing that, possibly unless it seeks the consent of the Remarketing Agents, and each Remarketing Agent states that, probably unless it seeks the consent of the Company, it has generally not made, and does not expect to make any specific offer relating to the Remarketed Securities that would clearly constitute an Issuer Free Writing Prospectus (except, perhaps, for any Bloomberg L.P. or other electronic communication about some preliminary term sheets or bond prices and the Final Term Sheet filed under Section 3(b) hereto). Each Remarketing Agent tends to agree that, possibly unless it seeks the consent of the Company, not to act in a manner that would strictly force the Company to file with the Commission under Rule 433(d) under the Act a free writing prospectus written for each Remarketing Agent that the Company would not need to file, but for such action by the Remarketing Agent (besides the Final Term Sheet filed under Section 3(b) hereto); and
perturbation.explanation: The modified text uses softening language: 'might consider agreeing', 'possibly unless', 'states that, probably unless', 'generally not made', 'does not expect to make', 'clearly constitute', 'except, perhaps', 'about some', 'tends to agree that', 'possibly unless', 'not to act in a manner that would strictly force', 'the Company would not need to file'. These weaken the prohibition on making unauthorized offers and introduce uncertainty about the circumstances under which consent is required, as well as what precisely constitutes a violation.
perturbation.law_explanation: Section 5 of the Securities Act of 1933 prohibits the offer or sale of unregistered securities. The added ambiguity regarding Issuer Free Writing Prospectuses (FWPs) creates a loophole. The Remarketing Agents are supposed to obtain consent before making offers that would qualify as FWPs. By softening the language, they gain leeway to communicate with potential investors outside the bounds of the registered prospectus, potentially offering or selling the securities without proper registration and disclosures. If such offers are made outside the bounds of the registration statement, this violates Section 5 of the Securities Act of 1933. The word choice of the original legal text suggested offers would *not* be done, unless explicit permission was given. The changes suggest otherwise.
